As a teacher for 35 years and a middle school sub for several more, I wonder about the value of sitting through a 40-minute class without talking.  The only situation I can see where this might be valuable is if there is a film (video!) of that duration.  We saw in the tiny excerpts of Dalton classes that much of that education involves discussion of topics presented.  Maybe these students should have more opportunity for meaningful discussions in the context of academics.

And do your own students get the same sort of stimulating education in their classes, including history and Latin? Or social studies and no music lessons, with lots of worksheets and multiple-choice tests?

My 3 children attended a public middle school in Manhattan and received a stellar education similar to the one you you described -- in addition, though, they learned with middle and lower income children from a variety of backgrounds, family types and SES -- and we didn't pay a dime. Similar opportunities are available in public schools, although  with FAR Larger class sizes -- if you live in the right neighborhood.

I have a Latina daughter who also received a significant scholarship at a similar school in Oakland, CA. With a tuition of 28,000 for middle school and 34,000 for high school.

Here is what she gets every day in middle school - Access to peer reviewed research from around the world; a choice of four foreign languages, six arts class, and four music classes. She has science (with a full laboratory), history, English, advanced Algebra, Computer Science / programming, Latin and art. She is expected to conduct herself well and is expected to complete 1.5 to 2 hours a night of homework and an additional 1 to 1.5 hours a night of project-based work collaborating with other students using Google docs and college level research documents.

I would like to say that this type of education should be available to all students, however, I do not believe it is true. My own middle school students do not sit through a 40 minute class without talking. Their parents would not support their children not talking for each class. Half of my students (the vast majority are Spanish speaking) will not complete more than 10 minutes of homework a night. I have parents coming to school complaining about 10 minutes of math and 10 minutes of science per night. The rigor of private school is not for every student. If students are not willing to do the hard work, they should not be given the access. For ANY student who is willing to continually do the hard work required, she or he should be given access.

Yelp's policies were put in place because people were trying to game the system and flood the ratings with positive reviews to change the total scoring. Many five stars would eventually eliminate any meaning of a single lone low rating. Consider that it is possible for a good place to have a customer have a bad experience of have a grudge. Any business that has only five stars... I take that with a grain of salt.

Also consider that businesses pay to be placed higher on Yelp search results. Doesn't it seem odd that location outliers appear high on their results but those who don't pay are nearer to the search locations.

I really like Angie's list myself. Ive had a good experience with them. Great business model too - wish I did it first. I generally trust what I read there and have written truthful extremely glowing reviews there due to my direct experiences. But I have also had a contractor actually offer to pay me to join Angie's List thinking that I had a great experience. I have also seen Angie's List put a company that I had a bad experience with in their bad box.

Myself, I would like a follow up to this article at an appropriate time in the future. I'm glad Schneiderman is doing something. The NY Attorney Generals have a good history, in my view, of setting high standards to protect consumers even if a topic is too controversial politically for anyone in Washington to actually risk doing something for the average Joe or Jane.

to reply to Frank - angies list is not that good and not what most people think it is.

I work with lots of contractors and none of the really good ones will participate with AL. AL will charge them about 10% just for the privilege of getting a contact. (let me be clear - AL charges you a fee to be a member, then charges the contractors a percentage of the price of the work.) AL always makes money (on both ends), but (1) you end up paying a lot more, and (2) most really good contractors won't "pay to play" with AL.

So, the ratings on AL are not what they seem - they are only ratings of those contractors who are willing to pay a lot of money to be listed.

Lois, you can count the number of kosher (Va'ad-certified) restaurants in Washington State on two hands. No, I'm wrong. I think you can count them on the fingers on one hand... you might be able to count the number of certified kosher restaurants in WA, OR, BC and AK on two hands, but it still might be in the one hand range ...

I'm guessing there a even with that miniscule amount of restaurants, people here would give them low ratings if it was appropriate.

I've seen people post everything from one to five stars for the vegan restaurants in the state (the only other viable option for someone like me). Yelp posts them, as long as they are articulate, which they seem to be.

Personally, I take all reviews (professional and non-professional) with a grain of salt. Too many positive ones means that either there is a cult following or the place is wildly out of my price range. Too few either means that the place is catering to a different clientele than the one that writes reviews in Yelp or that something snarky is going on.

Your article is interesting, but my husband and I had the opposite experience. We found that Yelp's rules about restaurant reviews are so stringent, and its criteria so odd, that it was impossible to get a favorable review about a restaurant published openly. We wrote Yelp for help in understanding what was going on and in getting our review seen, but it was not possible to have meaningful correspondence with a human at Yelp. We received mostly robotically delivered, boilerplate responses.

We have no personal connection with the restaurant involved, except that it is a small restaurant. It is a kosher restaurant, so perhaps that limitation led to too much excitement among kosher customers on Yelp, leading to too many five-star reviews from Yelp's point of view. Those reviews can be seen only if one subscribes to Yelp, and only if one figures out the key to reading the blocked (filtered) reviews. And they don't count in Yelp's average rating seen on the Google page. You write about restaurants trying to counter negative reviews with fake reviews. My husband and I were trying to counter the lone visible (one-star) Yelp review honestly and on our own initiative, and the other (all favorable) filtered reviews were doing the same (I could tell from reading them, even if Yelp couldn't).

I found the blocking of the favorable reviews to be a real miscarriage of justice! I hope that Yelp and these other pages don't get even worse in response to Mr. Schneiderman's investigation.

Martin, superb question. I used AL for a few days when Java was suspected of being a terrorist threat. Seriously, Dept. of Homeland Security sent a memo advising Java users to disable it until further notice.

Here is my fuzzy recollection from back then: AL is a fine thing. I am almost positive my solving speed dropped due to its response to my typing speed; but on the other hand it was hard to get used to a different way of navigating around the grid.

HOWEVER, what I did with the extra time tonight was to go back and read all the comments for the last 4 puzzles I completed (FRI XWP, SUN XWP only, Acrostic, MON XWP) and you know what? Your wife is hilarious; Wags could base a recurring character on her for humor value. And pecantart is a really fine writer. And fivethirtyam was extremely persuasive in urging people to do the Sunday Contest. She is so upbeat and charming (online) that I don't think she needs chrome on ANY body part in order to keep a man transfixed. She sold even me. But I am too lazy to install those new print cartridges, so I solved the contest part without printing anything out. We like mental workouts; and that was a mental workout. I used 3 windows on my computer screen.

Oh, you know what else? You all (communally, not Martin) gave a lot of hints. Hinting was such the norm that it was almost understood that people were hinting. Someone thought they perceived a hint in one of MY comments. Someone VERY smart.

So now, I'm entering the Contest.

We are now at a stage where we have to be asking this: what level of outrage will be required before we, as a nation, decide that something (whatever something is) must be done? It is coming. As these mass killings go on, sooner or later some deranged mind still functioning enough to make a plan will take a hundred or more lives at one time. Is that what it takes? Is this a body count war of attrition against indifference and screaming insistence that the founders of the nation, and god, wanted every man, woman and child to be packing?

It is entirely correct to call the reaction to the Navy Yard massacre "muted". Even here in the DC area, even around where I live where many people work for the govt. and for defense related concerns and on military installations, the reaction seems to have been mild. At a local gathering this past Sunday where 500 to a 1000 people pass through on a given day, no one mentioned the Navy Yard. There were no sad, long faces. No one was sharing concerns and asking the universal question: what can we do? Sunday, a few days after the shootings, everything was back to normal.

I am old enough to remember a time when the entire nation was shocked by mass killings. Things seemed to stop. A kind of stunned silence fell on communities and towns nationwide and people asked, "What is the world coming to?" Now we know. Mild indifference and blunt edged acceptance of what is almost, now, routine.

If only our lawmakers, our elected representatives, had one iota of whatever it takes to do the right thing.  There is no valid argument left for not instituting background checks to buy guns.  Our "leaders" try to obfuscate, to divert, to rationalize.  The world looks on in disbelief at an advanced nation unwilling, as Australia did, to come to terms with its gun and violence issue.  If only a few good representatives would do the right thing, even if it costs them politically.  Wouldn't a few saved lives be worth that miniscule "sacrifice"?

I agree that the response to the Navy Yard gun slayings was tepid, at best; and it creates a depressing, almost hopeless mindset for the American people, because it reminds us how detached we have become from our democracy of, by and for the people has become. In the sixties and seventies, one of the biggest threats to national wellbeing and decision making that reflected the hopes of most people was apathy. This threat is once again rearing its ugly, anti-democratic head, as policy is divorced from the needs of the American people.

In policy, after policy, the commercial interests and war making interests are served despite the absence of public support. Unfortunately, the media and the politicians, for the most part, live in the same insulated bubble that encourages a narrow political argument that centers on subjects that are unresponsive to the needs of the vast majorities of Americans.

Mass murder is one of the more depressing aspects of a new normal that accepts mass death over the rights of commercial gun-selling interests. More mass murders are inevitable and accepted as part of the American way of life.

Just have seen a footnote in the Wikipedia about Ordoliberalism:

"In Germany, ordoliberalism is often seen as a central reason for the German Wirtschaftswunder. However, there are also critics. According to Sebastian Dullien and Ulrike Guérot Ordoliberalism is a central reason for the German approach to euro crisis resolution which often has led to conflict with other European countries."

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordoliberalism#Opinions

It might be worth reading this, because it explains a lot of the approach to the crisis. And it might answer a question from P.Krugman yesterday, why there are no austerian economist - maybe because they don't call themself like this.
In particular, ordoliberals, unlike neoliberals, do not participate in the market. Ordoliberals also do believe, that markets tend to destabilize, providing fair competition is an essential task of the government. Even social issues must be supervised and are part of the modell. This is in contrast to a laissez-faire capitalism.
So Merkel is acting according to a larger economic philosophy. For me it's at the moment hard to say, if this philosophy is unique or very different to other western ecomonies - to me it seems at least very different to the US-economy.

The European Union, the Euro and open borders appear almost to be socio-economic experiments dreamed up by Euro bureaucrats.

The designs are grand but the implementation messy and the outcome uncertain.

I tend to agree with your sentiment Mathias. While more spending may have helped the US recover faster I don't necessarily think there would have been a similar outcome in the Euro zone - especially with disparate countries like Greece and Portugal and Spain and now Romania and Bulgaria entering the fold.

Ultimately for the European Union to succeed, all the countries in the Euro zone need to reach a similar level of economic activity and prosperity. Whether that happens by pulling down Germany and France to the levels of the poorer countries or pushing the latter up to the former is the question. Germany believes fiscal discipline, productivity and effiiciency are key to national prosperity. From a purely economic standpoint, I can't disagree.

From the political standpoint too, as long as Germany remains at center - with sensible policies and laws -and can successfully keep the fringe in check it seems to be destined to greater stability and prosperity.

Merkel's pragmatism, humility, intelligence and hard work make her a great leader. Ther German people are smart enough to see this and not fall for vacuous sound bites as we in the US sometimes tend to.

About EU: Europe had been erratic for quite a while (by the way, the US is too), and is looking to a strong germany for getting things back in line, but primary as a big payor and benefactor on our own account. But this is not the way this is working.
First - the more obvious reason, germany is not that rich, our wealth is the highly sophisticated industry, and that is where our money is. With this industry we can compete in a global market, it ensures us a sound foundation, but this foundation is much lower than most people are willing to see. In fact germany has the biggest low wage sector in europe, and the average wealth of a german household is half of that of a spain household and a fifth of a cypriot household (before the crisis).
Second - we really do believe that other countries are unhinged. Let's be honest, Greece is less competitive than india or pakistan and has the same corruption index as bolivia and worse than china. Does anybody really believe stimulus will fix that.
So, there is a lot of reason, that nothing will change at all. We will, at best, annoy people by making more rules, but don't expect more than that.

The civil attorney asks, "...do we really need another law to put more people in jail in the United States?”

The answer is "Yes!" for these reasons.

1. Civil suits require plaintiffs to advance thousands of dollars of their own money towards attorney fees. For the many women with no money, well, they get no attorney, no law suit, no day in court -- just enduring shame.

2. Criminal acts do not require victims to advance their own money and pursue their own cause. Instead, law enforcement (police), state attorneys, and courts take over the pursuit at taxpayer expense.

Imprisonment is much worse than a judgement. The former is real punishment, whereas the latter is something that can be trifled with for years.
